read.title: üìñ At Muttrah Souq
read.passage:
Ahmed and his cousin Hamad visited Muttrah Souq. It was Ahmed's first time at the famous traditional market.

Inside, Ahmed saw narrow covered walkways, colorful lights, and smelled frankincense. "This place is amazing!" he exclaimed.

They walked through winding lanes with hundreds of shops - textiles, silver jewelry, perfumes, and traditional items.

Ahmed stopped at a shop selling a beautiful silver khanjar keychain. "How much?" he asked politely.

"Ten rials," the owner replied.

Ahmed counted his money - only seven rials. "I don't have enough," he said sadly.

Hamad overheard. "Don't worry, cousin. I'll pay for it! Consider it an early birthday present."

"Really? Thank you so much!" Ahmed said gratefully. "I'll pay you back next week."

"No need," Hamad smiled. "But if you insist, help me with English homework instead!"

The shop owner wrapped the keychain carefully and gave them a receipt. "It's good to see young people helping each other," he said.

Ahmed attached the keychain to his school bag. "Every time I see it, I'll remember today."

They continued shopping and watched a shopkeeper explain bargaining to tourists. "In souqs, bargaining is tradition! I say one price, you offer lower, we meet in the middle!"

"So that's how bargaining works," Ahmed whispered. "But only in souqs - not in malls!"

Before leaving, they had karak chai for 500 baisa per cup.

"Today was great. Thanks again!" Ahmed said.

"Deal! English homework for the keychain!" Hamad laughed.

The keychain wasn't just a souvenir - it was a reminder of family, generosity, and a wonderful day at Oman's famous market!

read.title: üìñ Online vs. Traditional Shopping in Oman
read.passage:
Today, many Omanis shop online using phones or laptops. Websites and apps offer clothes, electronics, books, and even groceries. You can order at midnight and have it delivered the next day!

However, some people still prefer traditional markets like Nizwa Souq or Muttrah Souq. At these places, they can touch the products, smell the frankincense, and talk to sellers face-to-face. Bargaining is common - you might buy something for 20 OMR when it was first priced at 30 OMR.

Both types of shopping have advantages. Online shopping is fast and convenient - you can compare one thousand products in minutes! But souqs are full of culture and history. When you walk through Muttrah Souq, you see traditional Omani crafts that are hundreds of years old.

Young people often prefer online shopping because it saves time. But during Eid and special occasions, families still visit souqs together. It's not just about buying - it's about the experience.

Some Omani businesses now do both! They have a physical shop in the souq AND sell online. This way, they keep tradition alive while using modern technology.

Which do you prefer - clicking a button or walking through a souq?
